author: robbybienestar@pulzo-hermes.com
title: ¿Dormir mal hace subir de peso y cómo regular el sueño?
text: La falta de sueño o un sueño de mala calidad puede tener un impacto significativo en el aumento de peso. El sueño desempeña un papel fundamental en la regulación de hormonas asociadas con el hambre y el metabolismo. Cuando usted no descansa lo suficiente o tiene un sueño interrumpido, puede afectar el equilibrio hormonal. (Lea también: [Beneficios de comer pitaya: tenga un sistema digestivo más sano y evite el estreñimiento](http://v)) Dos hormonas clave en este proceso son la leptina y la grelina. La leptina, producida por las células de grasa, comunica al cerebro la sensación de saciedad después de comer. Por otro lado, la grelina, secretada por el estómago, estimula el apetito. Cuando se duerme poco, los niveles de leptina disminuyen, lo que puede disminuir la sensación de saciedad después de las comidas, mientras que los niveles de grelina aumentan, incrementando así el apetito. Además, la privación del sueño causa cambios en los niveles de otras hormonas como el cortisol conocido como la hormona del estrés. Los niveles elevados de cortisol influyen en cómo su cuerpo almacena la grasa y también aumenta el deseo de consumir alimentos ricos en calorías y carbohidratos. (Vea también: [Jugo de remolacha para subir las defensas: solo necesita 3 ingredientes](https://www.pulzo.com/recetas/como-hacer-jugo-remolacha-subir-defensas-quitar-anemia-PP3237387A#:~:text=Rico%20en%20antioxidantes%3A%20la%20remolacha,las%20defensas%20naturales%20del%20organismo.)) Adicionalmente, la falta de sueño impacta en su estilo de vida. Las personas que duermen poco o mal se sienten más fatigadas durante el día, lo que reduce su motivación para realizar ejercicio o preparar comidas saludables. Esto a su vez contribuye al aumento de peso. ¿Cómo regular el sueño y dormir bien? Siga estos pasos para poder descansar: - Establecer una rutina de sueño: es beneficioso acostarse y levantarse a la misma hora todos los días, incluyendo los fines de semana. Este hábito ayuda a regular el reloj interno y mejora la calidad del sueño. Antes de ir a la cama es útil adoptar una rutina relajante como tomar un baño tibio, leer un libro o practicar técnicas de respiración para señalar al cuerpo que es hora de dormir. - Cuidar la alimentación y el ejercicio: [es aconsejable evitar las comidas pesadas y la cafeína varias horas antes de acostarse](https://www.pulzo.com/vivir-bien/es-recomendable-comer-antes-dormir-cuanto-tiempo-debe-pasar-PP2881352A), ya que dificultan conciliar el sueño. El ejercicio regular mejora la calidad del sueño, pero es preferible realizarlo algunas horas antes de ir a la cama para permitir que el cuerpo se relaje adecuadamente antes de dormir. - Crear un entorno propicio para dormir: el entorno de sueño tiene un gran impacto en la calidad del descanso. Mantener la habitación fresca, oscura y tranquila es importante. Se pueden utilizar cortinas opacas, tapones para los oídos o una máscara para los ojos si es necesario. Además, es recomendable limitar el uso de dispositivos electrónicos antes de dormir. *Este artículo fue escrito y curado por periodistas del equipo de [Robby Bienestar](https://www.pulzo.com/noticias/robby-bienestar), con apoyo de una inteligencia artificial que utiliza machine learning para producir texto. LO ÚLTIMO [Vivir Bien] Hace 2 horas [Esta es la ruta del vino en Colombia para fin de año; licor está en su mejor momento](/vivir-bien/ruta-vino-colombia-cuales-son-mejores-lugares-visitar-PP3349493A) [Vivir Bien] Hace 2 horas [Cómo cerrar ciclos y dejar ir lo que nos duele este 31 de diciembre; rituales, 'tips' y más](/vivir-bien/rituales-iniciar-ano-nuevo-velas-carta-liberadora-palo-santo-PP3349485A) [Vivir Bien]

author: Sierra Rains
title: Alleged drug dealer accused of murder after Nashville, TN woman's overdose death
text:
(Getty Images) by: Sierra Rains
Posted: Jun 13, 2024 / 10:51 AM CDT
Updated: Jun 13, 2024 / 11:31 AM CDT
SHARE
NASHVILLE, Tenn. (WKRN) — An alleged drug dealer is facing multiple charges after Metro Nashville police said he supplied drugs to a woman who ended up overdosing on fentanyl.
Donald Frank Swagler, 53, was arrested and booked into the Davidson County jail on Wednesday, June 12. Court records show he has been indicted by a grand jury on multiple charges related to the woman’s death on June 1, 2023.
CRIME TRACKER | Read the latest crime news from Middle Tennessee Donald Swagler Jr. (Courtesy: Metro Nashville Police Department) The charges against him include second-degree murder and four counts of delivery of a schedule 2 controlled substance. According to the indictment, Swagler is believed to have delivered fentanyl to people on multiple occasions between May 16 and May 28.
Authorities said the woman’s death was the direct result of the “unlawful, intentional, knowing, or reckless distribution, delivery, or dispensation of fentanyl or carfentanil.”
⏩ Read today’s top stories on wkrn.com
As of Thursday, June 13, Swagler was still behind bars with a $500,000 bond.

author: Sports Business Journal
title: FIFA President Gianni Infantino says U.S. will be welcoming to international fans for 2026 World Cup
text: FIFA President Gianni Infantino on Wednesday said that he has “received assurances from the White House that, despite increased scrutiny of visitors to the country since President Donald Trump’s return to office, fans from abroad will be welcomed for the 2026 World Cup,” according to Steven Goff of the WASHINGTON POST. After meeting Trump last month in D.C., Infantino met with U.S. Attorney General Pam Bondi and FBI Director Kash Patel last week in Miami to “discuss security and potential issues involving the expected hundreds of thousands of fans from abroad” expected to attend the tournament. Infantino on Tuesday “discussed matters” with Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy. Infantino on Wednesday said, “It is very important we have the engagement of the different government agencies to make sure that security is guaranteed, that fans can travel to the U.S. and around the U.S., that transportation is working perfectly, that the world will be welcomed.” Goff notes in early March, Trump established a White House task force that he will chair to “coordinate federal agencies in ‘planning, organizing and executing’” both the Club World Cup this summer and 2026 World Cup. Infantino said, “We got all these guarantees from the government, who is very, very engaged to make sure this Club World Cup is a huge success, because this will pave the path as well for next year” (WASHINGTON POST, 4/16).

author: Lauren Collins
title: Lower Mainland, Vancouver Island windstorm could see gusts up to 100 km/h
text:
Environment Canada is warning of a windstorm that could see gusts of up to 100 km/h in parts of the Lower Mainland, Vancouver Island and the Sunshine Coast.
A low-pressure system is expected to hit the west coast of Vancouver Island and Greater Victoria Friday (Dec. 13), and move to the rest of B.C's south coast by Saturday. The windstorm is expected to have gusts between 70 and 100 km/h in Metro Vancouver and Vancouver Island, as well as the Sunshine Coast. The wind is expected to ease by the afternoon.
East Vancouver Island, from Courtenay to Campbell River, also has a rainfall warning in effect. Between 50 and 70 millimetres are expected.
Environment Canada says that on the west coast of the Island, there is the potential threat of coast flooding from high tides.
The weather warning adds there could be damage to buildings, and loose objects could be tossed by the wind, leading to injuries or other damage.
As wind aligns w/ high tides,— ECCC Weather British Columbia (@ECCCWeatherBC)
[#coastalflooding]is forecast near midday Saturday for W Vancouver Island where [#stormsurge]& wave run up may rise 1 m above highest tide. Risk of coastal flooding for Victoria (~50 cm). [#bcstorm] [https://t.co/7hORw9itwI] [pic.twitter.com/l8XB5wEsl5] [December 13, 2024]

author: Danette Mitchell
title: Danette Mitchell: Kwanzaa principles must last all year
text: While I respect the seven days of the Kwanzaa principles known as Nguzo Saba, the full benefit of honoring them, which runs from Dec. 26 until Jan. 1, can only be achieved if Black people, in particular, actively apply the principles throughout the year. Dr. Maulana Karenga, professor and chair of Africana Studies at California State University, Long Beach, created Kwanzaa in 1966. The Black American celebration, honoring family and community and the values of ancient African cultures, includes (Umoja) unity, (Kujichagulia) self-determination, (Ujima) collective work and responsibility, (Ujamaa) cooperative economics, (Nia) purpose, (Kuumba) creativity, and (Imani) faith. Reflecting on the Swahili-worded principles, Black people can use them to construct a culture of empowerment. Black Empowerment is a lifestyle and not an annual ritual or event. Unity in our family, community, nation, and race is a powerful tool and the foundation for enacting and sustaining meaningful change. Consider this: Many centuries ago, God, whom many believe is the creator of humanity, saw like-minded people building a tower that would reach the heavens. While their grand vision represented an unrighteous endeavor, according to God, their unfinished work was magnificent. God even said that nothing they planned together would be impossible because they mastered “unity.” Unity begins in strong families and then spreads into the community and the nation. Accomplishing tangible and measurable goals requires unifying, organizing, and mobilizing around an agreed common cause, like reparations, staying on code, and being uncompromising. Unity is the foundational principle of the Nguzo Saba, for without it, all the other principles suffer. Self-determination requires the community to define itself, name itself, create for itself, and speak for itself. Black people should stay on their square about issues and concerns that are significant to them and advocate for them. Movements only require a critical mass, not everyone, to get the job done. In many cases, hardly anyone wants to propose tailored solutions for Black problems. Society remains more comfortable recommending broad minority solutions and using ambiguous terms and language for issues that are unique to Black people alone. Specificity matters. Black people should also define their own definition of beauty, success, excellence, family, and gender roles for themselves. Gender divides don’t move the Black community forward. Collective work and responsibility require that Black Americans build and maintain their community together and make others’ problems their own, solving them together. The community can’t continue fighting other groups’ issues who don’t have the legacy or systematic disadvantages as Black people. Or believe an injustice to one Black person doesn’t affect all of us. Dr. Karenga describes cooperative economics as the fourth principle, which means the Black community must include entrepreneurship as a viable career path and support each other’s businesses so that all profit. Black-owned businesses must lead to corporations, institutions, and industries and be Black-conscious. Those who claim to speak for Black people — no matter who they are — must be for and about Black people, supporting a group-based vision and committed leadership. Purpose requires intentionally bettering the community to restore Black people to their traditional greatness. At the same time, creativity, the sixth principle, requires Black people to use their creative energies to leave our community more beautiful and beneficial than we inherited it. Creativity should extend to thriving Black schools, research centers and hospitals, and other industries rather than be limited to entertainment and sports. Having Black-owned entities doesn’t translate to segregation. Being Black-owned provides the same rights and privileges that every other group has — the right to choose. And control one’s resources to create generational wealth, building a sustainable model for the next generation. Above all, faith, which is the final principle. Faith is to “believe in our Creator, our people, our parents, our teachers, our leaders, and the righteousness and victory of our struggle.” Faith is necessary to operate the other six Kwanzaa principles. As Dr. Karenga said, “Without unity, the first principle, we cannot begin our most important work. Without faith, we cannot sustain it.” So, as 2024 nears, Black people should commit to Kwanzaa year-round as the war to achieving Black Empowerment is far from over. By implementing one Kwanzaa principle for 52 days each and doing the task each one represents, we can make a difference in our communities, the nation, and the world. — Vacaville author Danette Mitchell is a social issues advocate. 2022 Women of the Year Congressional Award Recipient. E-mail: damitchell@earthlink.net.

author: Haadiza Ogwude, Cincinnati Enquirer
title: Winter Storm could bring heavy snow, ice this weekend in Greater Cincinnati
text:
Winter Storm could bring heavy snow, ice this weekend in Greater Cincinnati Haadiza Ogwude, Cincinnati Enquirer Updated Fri, January 3, 2025 at 3:26 PM UTC 4 min read
Update, 10:13 a.m.: Villa Hills, in Kenton County, has declared a snow emergency taking effect Sunday morning due to the possibility of inclement winter weather over the weekend and early next week.
"This emergency declaration will assist the public works crews with snow removal and combat the hazards from the residential streets and roadways," the Villa Hills Police Department said in a Facebook post .
Police said officers will start issuing citations and removing vehicles from roadways once the snow emergency goes into effect.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement Some Greater Cincinnati businesses have already closed in response to the anticipated winter weather.
The Anderson Ferry, which transports commuters across the Ohio River between Northern Kentucky and Cincinnati's West Side, announced on Friday it is closed until further notice due to wind.
More: Weather terms to know as possible winter storm approaches Greater Cincinnati
Update 8:39 a.m.: The National Weather Service in Wilmington states that total snow accumulations between 4 and 8 inches and ice accumulations of one-quarter an inch will be possible Sunday through Monday.
Previous reporting: The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a winter storm watch for Greater Cincinnati on Friday as a potentially harsh system is forecast to make its way into the area on Sunday.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement The winter storm watch will be in effect from Sunday until Monday evening for Hamilton, Clermont, Butler, and Warren counties in Ohio, Boone, Kenton, and Campbell counties in Kentucky, and Dearborn, Franklin, Switzerland, and Ohio counties in Indiana.
Heavy mixed precipitation will be possible. Forecasters are predicting that total snow accumulation s between 5 and 10 inches and ice accumulations up to a tenth of an inch will also be possible.
There is a 52% chance of seeing 6 inches of snow or more in the Cincinnati region from the winter storm expected to hit this weekend. The ice may cause power outages and tree damage. Forecasters add that travel could be nearly impossible as hazardous conditions could impact the Monday morning and evening commutes.
Widespread snow will move across the area Friday morning ahead of the upcoming storm. So far, accumulations appear to be less than an inch. The snow will taper off through mid-morning as a cold front moves through.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement More in U.S. Passengers kicked off flight with nowhere to go in travel nightmare: ‘People out on the streets like animals’ The Independent Dear Abby: I told a horrible secret to a relative — now she’s threatening she’ll tell my children NY Post The Memo: New Orleans mass killing gets pulled into partisan political battle The Hill Matt Gaetz Debuts His New OANN Show To Maybe Not The Feedback He Expected HuffPost However, there may be some slick spots on area roadways through the morning commute, especially on bridges and overpasses. Motorists, make sure to exercise caution on Friday morning.
Temperatures Friday will range from the mid-20s in the northwest to around 30 degrees in the southeast, with wind gusts in the 20 to 30 mph range.
Ohio and Kentucky snow emergencies: What do the levels mean?
Mainly dry but cold conditions are expected on Saturday, with highs in the 20s. Precipitation is expected to return as early as Sunday morning and will continue into Monday, with snow being the primary precipitation type through the day. Snow will finally begin to taper off by sunset Monday.
A Winter Storm Watch has been issued for most of our counties for the Sunday/Monday system. There is increasing confidence that a swath of significant snow totals is expected, along with a wintry-mix that could result in ice accums near/south of the OH River. Stay tuned for more! pic.twitter.com/Ppi9aT1fVs
— NWS Wilmington OH (@NWSILN) January 3, 2025
How much snow will Cincinnati get this weekend? According to the NWS , Cincinnati is expected to receive approximately 6 inches of snow Sunday through Monday. However, the city could get as much as 9 inches on the high-end.
Advertisement Advertisement Advertisement As of 6:42 a.m. Friday, there is a 95% chance that Cincinnati will receive at least two inches of snow this weekend. There is a 52% chance that Cincinnati could receive the predicted 6 inches of snow and a 23% chance that the city could get up to 8 inches.
The National Weather Service in Wilmington expects the Cincinnati region to see 6 inches of snow from the winter storm this weekend. There is a 52% chance of seeing that amount. There is a 80% chance of seeing 4 inches of snow and a 23% chance of seeing 8 inches of snow. Greater Cincinnati ice accumulation totals The Cincinnati area is expected to receive over a tenth of an inch of total ice accumulation.
Predictions for ice accumulations in the region from the winter storm taking aim this weekend. Advertisement Advertisement Detailed 7-day Cincinnati weather forecast Friday: A chance of snow before 7 a.m. Mostly cloudy, with a high near 33. Northwest wind 7 to 16 mph, with gusts as high as 26 mph. The chance of precipitation is 40%. Total daytime snow accumulation of less than a half inch possible.
Friday night: Partly cloudy, with a low of around 18. Northwest wind 6 to 10 mph, with gusts as high as 20 mph.
Saturday: Sunny, with a high near 29. West wind 6 to 8 mph.
Saturday night: Mostly cloudy, with a low of around 19. Calm wind.
Sunday: Snow before 4 p.m., then snow, possibly mixed with freezing rain. The snow could be heavy at times. High near 29. Calm wind becoming east around 6 mph in the afternoon. The chance of precipitation is 90%. Little or no ice accumulation is expected. New snow accumulation of 2 to 4 inches is possible.
Advertisement Advertisement Sunday night: Snow and freezing rain. Low of around 24. The chance of precipitation is 100%. New ice accumulation of 0.1 to 0.3 of an inch is possible. New snow accumulation of 2 to 4 inches is possible.
Monday: Snow likely, mainly before 1 p.m. Mostly cloudy, with a high near 30. The chance of precipitation is 70%.
Wednesday: Partly sunny, with a high near 21.
Thursday: Mostly sunny, with a high near 20.
Source: National Weather Service, Wilmington.
This article originally appeared on Cincinnati Enquirer: Winter Storm: Cincinnati could see 4-8 inches of snow, icing possible
